body: LBs distribute traffic across servers to prevent any single one from overloading. Key for high availability!
Vertical: Adding more RAM/CPU to one machine. Horizontal: Adding more machines. Horizontal is king for scale!
Store frequently accessed data in memory (like Redis) to reduce DB load and speed up response times. ⚡
Splitting a large DB into smaller, faster pieces (shards) across different servers. Essential for huge datasets.
A network of servers globally that serves static content (images/JS) from the location closest to the user.
Breaking a monolith into small, independent services that communicate via APIs. Great for team scaling!
A single entry point for all clients. It handles routing, authentication, and rate limiting in one place.
Decouple services using tools like Kafka or RabbitMQ. Allows async processing so systems don't wait on each other.
SQL: Structured, rigid schema, great for ACID. NoSQL: Flexible, horizontally scalable, great for unstructured data.
In a distributed system, you can only pick 2: Consistency, Availability, or Partition Tolerance. Choose wisely!
